heading: blood treatment on the go
subheading: a medical device developed by a research team in washington state may be able to deliver constant, portable treatment to patients suffering from leukemia and aids.
author: reuters
text: the us department of energy said on friday that its scientists had developed a portable blood irradiator that should help make it easier to treat patients for leukemia, hiv infection, and other diseases. the device, about the size of a well-used pencil, employs a radioactive element known as thulium-170 to kill white blood cells.read ongoing med-tech coverage - - - - - -such therapy is used to treat cancers such as leukemia and lymphomas, in which white blood cells become cancerous and must be destroyed; other immune diseases, including hiv infection; and the early rejection of bone marrow transplants.the team at pacific northwest national laboratory in richland, washington, said the mobile unit would allow a patient to get constant therapy, as opposed to receiving stop-and-start treatment at a medical facility."studies indicate the levels of circulating lymphocytes fell to near zero within one to two weeks following placement of the irradiator, with subsequent depletion of lymphocytes from the regional lymph nodes and spleen," the department said in a statement.it also helped delay rejection of bone marrow transplants.copyright
